awd_titl_txt: Direct Probing of Organic Peroxy Radical Autoxidation and Cross Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Division of Chemistry. Professor Joel Thornton of the University of Washington and his group investigate what happens to reactive organic carbon species in the Earth's atmosphere. The highly reactive organic peroxy radicals are common species produced when carbon-based (organic) compounds degrade in the environment. Their detection and quantification is difficult because of their reactivity. Often only a total of organic peroxy radicals are measured, or only early decomposition products are identified. This project involves novel laboratory studies of the reactivity of these species which provides more detailed information than previously possible. An accurate understanding of the fundamental pathways of environmental degradation is crucial to determining what happens to pollutants as they naturally cycle through the Earth's environment. Improved experimental data are necessary for understanding how fuel combustion impacts the atmosphere, aquatic ecosystems, and soil composition.  The project provides educational and training opportunities for graduate students, undergraduates in chemistry and atmospheric sciences, and a postdoctoral research fellow. To inform the public of the results of this research, a computer animation is being produced in collaboration with a documentary filmmaker. This film shows how organic peroxy radicals produced in forests contribute to atmospheric particle formation and growth.  This research is important to society as it promotes public health and understanding of weather and storms.

This project uses fast flow tube reactors coupled to high resolution time of flight and orbitrap mass spectrometers. These techniques allow researchers to identify and simultaneously track nearly all individual organic peroxy radicals and their cross-reaction products. Reaction tracking of a suite of relevant starting compounds, purchased commercially or synthesized by collaborators, is done as a function of reaction time. These experiments provide quantitative insights into the rates and products of gas-phase organic carbon degradation under typical environmental conditions. Isotopic labeling and competitive reactant experiments allow for tests of hypothesized reaction mechanisms and independent rate quantification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview

This project studied the chemistry of volatile organic compounds (VOC), specifically the reactive intermediates that are created upon oxdiation of VOC in the air known as organic peroxy radicals (RO2.). We developed and used a novel flow reactor and obtained custom synthesized VOC with a portion of the molecule replaced with an isotope that allows tracking of the fate of that molecule. This experimental combination allowed us to uniquely probe this chemistry to provide constraints on type of reactions these RO2. a undergo and how fast. Such information can be used to model the impact of VOC emissions on atmospheric composition, air quality, and climate.

 

Intellectual Merit

VOC are emitted throughout the environment, naturally, e.g. by vegetation, and by human activities such as fossil fuel use, paints and solvent use, and perfumes and scents. RO2. are key intermediates in the degradation of VOC, as well as organic compounds in soils, combustion systems, food, and the atmosphere. RO2. transformations remain uncertain due to their high reactivity and complex array of possibilities as their size increases. Our experimetnal studies allowed improved quantitative understanding of the reactions RO2. undergo and the impacts these reactions might have on atmospheric composition. In particular we mostly focused on a suite of compounds known as monoterpenes, some of the most common natural and consumer product VOC, and on a process by which the RO2. that form from their initial reaction in the atmosphere undergo self-reactions, known as autoxidation, to end up high oxygenated, or by which they react with each other to form larger moleculas known as accretion. Both of these processes can lead to molecules which condense to form fine particulate matter in the air, known to degrade air quality with negative health effects.

We found that these compounds are efficient at forming highly oxygenated molecules and accretion products, and provided more refined quantitative descriptions of how they do so in the air by directly measuring the highly reactive RO2. that form and the products of their transformations on sub-second timescales. This information provides guidance for describing the fate of VOC in the environment using computer models to make predictions about the impact of changes in their emissions, either by natural or anthropogenic sources.

 

Broader Impacts

Understanding the fundamental pathways of the environmental degradation of volatile organic compounds is important to describing the natural and perturbed cycling of carbon through Earth systems. Moreover, this research intersects with broader environmental science and policy activities as RO2. are intermediates in fossil and biofuel combustion, water purification, and the formation of atmospheric ozone and particulate matter. Our research findings  improve the accuracy of air quality and coupled chemistry-climate models, as well as provide a broader understanding of transformation of organic material in soil and water.

The project also provided educational and training opportunities for three graduate and an undergraduate student in chemistry and atmospheric sciences. These students learned to operate state of the art instrumentation capable of detecting highly reactive intermediates at parts per trillion levels, online and in real time. They also learned to design experiments and develop methodology for detecting trace reactive compounds in the air. 

The project contributed to research infracstructure through the development of our novel apparatus and in particular a new ionization region for mass spectrometry. This region has greatly improved our ability to detect reactive trace gases in air, and is now being duplicated both by national laboratories and our own research group for uses beyond this project.


Last Modified: 01/01/2023
Modified by: Joel A Thornton

Image
  • This image shows the some of the first steps in the reaction pathway of alpha-pinene, one of the most commonly emitted monoterpenes, initiated by atmospheric photooxidation. Bold numbers show the quantitative yields and rates determined in our project.
    Joel Thornton
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Joel A Thornton
    Example chemistry studied and results
